In-class Exercise 4

Author

Fangyuan Zhu

Published

February 4, 2023

1 Get started

In this In-class exercise, we will explore more interesting packages to visualize data with statistical summary information shown in the plots.

2 Packages used

Packages will be used in this exercise are:

  • plotly

  • tidyverse

  • DT

  • patchwork

  • ggstatsplot

  • readr

Show the code 
pacman::p_load(ggplot2, plotly, readr, tidyverse, DT, patchwork, ggstatsplot, readxl, see, parameters, performance, dplyr)

3 Data used

Data we will use in this exercise is Exam_data.csv, and we can import the data with codes chunk below.

Show the code 
exam_data<-read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

4 Working with visual variable: plot_ly() method

Today we are going to explore the function plot_ly() to create an interactive plot.

Show the code 
plot_ly(data = exam_data,
        x = ~ENGLISH,
        y = ~MATHS,
        color = ~RACE)

5 Working with ggplotly function

Show the code 
p<-ggplot(data = exam_data,
          aes(x = MATHS,
              y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point(dotsize = 1) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100),
                  ylim = c(0,100))

ggplotly(p)

6 Working with ggstatsplot package

Show the code 
ggbetweenstats(
  data = exam_data,
  x = GENDER,
  y = MATHS,
  type = "np",
  massages = FALSE
)

Show the code 
ggscatterstats(
  data = exam_data,
  x = MATHS,
  y = ENGLISH,
  marginal = FALSE
)

7 Regression modeling

Show the code 
car_resale <- read_xls("data/ToyotaCorolla.xls", 
                       "data")
car_resale

#   Radio <dbl>, Mistlamps <dbl>, Sport_Model <dbl>, Backseat_Divider <dbl>, …
Show the code 
my_sum<-exam_data%>%
  group_by(RACE)%>%
  summarise(
    n = n(),
    mean = mean(MATHS),
    sd = sd(MATHS)
  )%>%
  mutate(se = sd/sqrt(n-1))
Show the code 
model<-lm(Price ~ Age_08_04 + Mfg_Year + KM +
            Weight + Guarantee_Period, data = car_resale)
model

Call:
lm(formula = Price ~ Age_08_04 + Mfg_Year + KM + Weight + Guarantee_Period, 
    data = car_resale)

Coefficients:
     (Intercept)         Age_08_04          Mfg_Year                KM  
      -2.637e+06        -1.409e+01         1.315e+03        -2.323e-02  
          Weight  Guarantee_Period  
       1.903e+01         2.770e+01
Show the code 
check_c <- check_collinearity(model)
plot(check_c)

Show the code 
ggplot(my_sum) +
  geom_errorbar(
    aes(x = RACE,
        ymin = mean - se,
        ymax = mean + se),
    width = 0.2,
    colour = "black",
    alpha = 0.9,
    size = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_point(aes(
    x = RACE,
    y = mean),
    stat = "identity",
    color = "red",
    size = 1.5,
    alpha = 1)

Show the code 
model[["coefficients"]]
     (Intercept)        Age_08_04         Mfg_Year               KM 
   -2.636783e+06    -1.409333e+01     1.314938e+03    -2.323290e-02 
          Weight Guarantee_Period 
    1.902743e+01     2.769708e+01

## 1 Get started

In this In-class exercise, we will explore more interesting packages to visualize data with statistical summary information shown in the plots.

## 2 Packages used

Packages will be used in this exercise are:

-   *plotly*

-   *tidyverse*

-   *DT*

-   *patchwork*

-   *ggstatsplot*

-   *readr*

```{r}
pacman::p_load(ggplot2, plotly, readr, tidyverse, DT, patchwork, ggstatsplot, readxl, see, parameters, performance, dplyr)
```

## 3 Data used

Data we will use in this exercise is *Exam_data.csv,* and we can import the data with codes chunk below.

```{r}
exam_data<-read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")
```

## 4 Working with visual variable: *plot_ly()* method

Today we are going to explore the function `plot_ly()` to create an interactive plot.

```{r}
plot_ly(data = exam_data,
        x = ~ENGLISH,
        y = ~MATHS,
        color = ~RACE)
```

## 5 Working with *ggplotly* function

```{r}
p<-ggplot(data = exam_data,
          aes(x = MATHS,
              y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point(dotsize = 1) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100),
                  ylim = c(0,100))

ggplotly(p)
```

## 6 Working with *ggstatsplot* package

```{r}
ggbetweenstats(
  data = exam_data,
  x = GENDER,
  y = MATHS,
  type = "np",
  massages = FALSE
)
```

```{r}
ggscatterstats(
  data = exam_data,
  x = MATHS,
  y = ENGLISH,
  marginal = FALSE
)
```

## 7 Regression modeling

```{r}
car_resale <- read_xls("data/ToyotaCorolla.xls", 
                       "data")
car_resale
```

```{r}
my_sum<-exam_data%>%
  group_by(RACE)%>%
  summarise(
    n = n(),
    mean = mean(MATHS),
    sd = sd(MATHS)
  )%>%
  mutate(se = sd/sqrt(n-1))
```

```{r}
model<-lm(Price ~ Age_08_04 + Mfg_Year + KM +
            Weight + Guarantee_Period, data = car_resale)
model
```

```{r}
check_c <- check_collinearity(model)
plot(check_c)
```

```{r}
ggplot(my_sum) +
  geom_errorbar(
    aes(x = RACE,
        ymin = mean - se,
        ymax = mean + se),
    width = 0.2,
    colour = "black",
    alpha = 0.9,
    size = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_point(aes(
    x = RACE,
    y = mean),
    stat = "identity",
    color = "red",
    size = 1.5,
    alpha = 1)

model[["coefficients"]]
```
